questions.question_text: Each workflow rule applies to a single object, such as leads, accounts, or opportunities.

The support team has asked the System Administrator to automate the notification of a customer's support plan ending - they would like for the Customer Support
Rep to receive an email 30 days before the Support Plan Expires (Support Plan Expiration Date is on the Account record). What will the system administrator do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A for sure. I have one of this in the company I am currently working

Can someone explain, I though Workflow rules gets triggered when record is created/updated. Then how is it able to trigger email before 30 days supposing that particular record is not being updated by the user.
Just because of the fact that that in the ending clause it states "use an email action to notify the assigned Support Rep" which sort of fulfils the criteria based on the question.

it would be inefficient for the rep to receive an email with a date on it that could be any time in the future with a 30 days from that date to the expiry date. It's better to actually receive the email 30 days to expiry, that way the rep knows they need to start engaging with the customer and don't forget about it.
Can someone explain why B does not work in this situation?

choices.B: Create a workflow rule with an immediate action to email the Support rep but with a due date of 30 days before the Support Expiration Date
choices.C: Create an Apex trigger to fire 30 days before Support Plan Expiration Date and use an email action to notify the assigned Support Rep
choices.A: Create a workflow rule with a time-based trigger to fire 30 days before the Support Plan Expiration Date and use an email action to notify the assigned Support Rep

The system administrator was testing workflow rules and needs to delete pending time-based workflow actions. How can he/she do this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Could be Deactivate as well, but the way this was questioned looks like the Sys Admin is testing it. I would just remove the action instead. So C

Selected Answer: C
should be C
The workflow rule has to de deactivated

comments.content: The workflow rule can be deactivated but it is not a must. Actions in the Time-based Workflow queue can be deleted without deactivation of the workflow rule, however, whenever the criteria are met again new actions in the Time-based Workflow queue will appear again, IMO.
As it mentioned as a test, I would just remove the action rather than deactivating
Setup->Monitor-->Time-Based Workflow--> Then search record and delete

discussion.content: Where can you access that queue?

choices.D: Reset passwords for all users of the org
choices.C: Delete the actions in the Time-based Workflow queue
